pages.text: Nickel is a chemical element with the symbol Ni and atomic number 28. It is a silvery-white lustrous metal with a slight golden tinge. Nickel belongs to the transition metals and is hard and ductile. Pure nickel, powdered to maximize the reactive surface area, shows a significant chemical activity, but larger pieces are slow to react with air under standard conditions because an oxide layer forms on the surface and prevents further corrosion (passivation)

. Even so, pure native nickel is found in Earth's crust only in tiny amounts, usually in ultramafic rocks, and in the interiors of larger nickel-$(l:materials/Iron)iron$(/l) meteorites that were not exposed to oxygen when outside Earth's atmosphere.$(p)Meteoric nickel is found in combination with $(l:materials/Iron)iron$(/l), a reflection of the origin of those elements as major end products of supernova nucleosynthesis. An $(l:materials/Iron)iron$(/l)–nickel mixture is thought to

compose Earth's outer and inner cores.$(p)Use of nickel (as a natural meteoric nickel–iron alloy) has been traced as far back as 3500 BCE. Nickel was first isolated and classified as a chemical element in 1751 by Axel Fredrik Cronstedt, who initially mistook the ore for a $(l:materials/Copper)copper$(/l) mineral, in the $(l:materials/Cobalt)cobalt$(/l) mines of Los, Hälsingland, Sweden. The element's name comes from a mischievous sprite of German

miner mythology, Nickel (similar to Old Nick), who personified the fact that $(l:materials/Copper)copper$(/l)-nickel ores resisted refinement into $(l:materials/Copper)copper$(/l). An economically important source of nickel is the $(l:materials/Iron)iron$(/l) ore limonite, which often contains 1–2% nickel. Nickel's other important ore minerals include $(l:ores/Pentlandite)pentlandite$(/l) and a mixture of Ni-rich natural silicates known as $(l:ores/Garnierite)garnierite$(/l). Major production sites include the Sudbury region in Canada (which is thought to be of
meteoric origin), New Caledonia in the Pacific, and Norilsk in Russia.
